title: 103_hr4463
content: The "Health Care Reform Assessment Act of 1994" is identified as the short title. Strategies for assessing the impact of health care reform are outlined in the Act. Within 90 days of enactment, the Secretary of Health and Human Services will seek an agreement with a nonprofit organization to study the impact of health care reform legislation nationally. The study aims to assess reforms' effects on goals like coverage security, administrative simplicity, cost savings, individual responsibility, care quality, choice, and health status. The Secretary will require a report from the organization conducting the study on indicators of national progress towards meeting the goals of health care reform, appropriate study designs, and data elements for measuring these indicators. The curr_chunk discusses the special requirements and methods needed to access confidential data for measuring health care reform indicators, establishing a core set of primary data, and coordinating information sharing between Federal, State, and local agencies. The curr_chunk discusses the nature, scope, and frequency of reports needed for evaluating health reform efforts, overall cost estimates for obtaining and evaluating this information, and ways the assessment findings could be utilized by various groups. Authorization of $1,000,000 is provided for the study under this section. SEC. 3. Developing baseline for evaluating health care reform. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will collaborate with the Institute of Medicine to develop baseline information for measuring access to, quality, and cost of healthcare for permanent residents of the United States. The purpose is to assess the impact of healthcare reform efforts at national, regional, and state levels. The Secretary will collaborate with the Institute of Medicine to develop baseline information for measuring healthcare access, quality, and cost for US residents. Recommendations under section 2(c) will include study designs, data sources, and indicators. Coordination with the organization conducting the study under section 2 is encouraged for maximum cooperation. A report must be submitted within 30 months after the enactment of the Act, containing information and assessments related to healthcare reform. The implementation of health care reform focuses on access, quality, cost, and public health status. Information will be reported separately for public and private sectors, and different types of services. Authorization of $3,000,000 for a study on various healthcare services in public and private sectors.
